awd_titl_txt: LEAPS-MPS: Unraveling the Galaxy-Cosmic Web Connection using Monte Carlo Physarum Machine
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).  All of the galaxies in the Universe are embedded in a cosmic web of filaments of material. One of the open questions in galactic astrophysics is how the structure and mass distribution of galaxies might depend on the structure of the filaments in which they are embedded. This work will explore how the cosmic web affects the structure and evolution of galaxies, and in turn how galaxy evolution and the expelling of material might affect the cosmic web. The program will be supported at a Hispanic Serving Institution, and will draw undergraduate researchers from under-represented groups. The team will also initiate and after-school outreach effort at a local high school where high school students will have the opportunity to work on actual science data from the project, and interface with project personnel. 

The team will deploy a simulation routine called the Monte Carlo Physarum Machine (MCPM), which incorporates filamentary structures while providing environmental density estimates even at the very low densities of the intergalactic medium. The MCPM is a computational model designed to reconstruct physically plausible density fields over sparse discrete data – in this case, these are primarily observed galaxies (positions and masses), and alternatively simulated baryonic/dark matter halos. This model is underlined by the optimal transport theory, obtaining network-like structures that interconnect data according to the principle of least action. Given that exact solutions to optimal transport problems are typically NP-hard, MCPM relies on a biologically inspired solution: emulating three-dimensional growth patterns of Physarum polycephalum ‘slime mold’, which is known to provide good approximations to this class of problems. From a computational perspective, MCPM is a stochastic model based on a combination of a discrete and a continuous component. The discrete component is an ensemble of particle-like agents that freely explore the simulation domain. The continuous component is a pair of 3D scalar lattices: one that represents the concentration of an environmental marker that guides the agents through the input data, and one that accumulates the spatio-temporal density of the agents and represents the actual solution.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Galaxies are the biggest building blocks in the Universe, playing host to billions of stars.  Some are thriving, vigorously forming new generations of stars, while others effectively halted star formation billions of years ago.  It is well known that galaxies living in densely populated neighborhoods such as galaxy clusters tend to be of the latter type, 'red and dead'.  However, connecting these neighborhoods is a vast 'cosmic web', a network of filaments that, like highways, host smaller galaxy communities between the big galaxy cluster cities. It is not well understood how galaxies are impacted by where they live within the cosmic web, and part of the reason is the difficulty in finding and characterizing the cosmic web among maps of galaxies.  

Our team has developed a methodology to map the cosmic web by mimicking the growth and movement of slime mold to unveil the cosmic web connecting these galaxies, which appear like the tiny dots of towns on a map. Through this NSF LEAPS-MPS program, which directly funded the training of three graduate students and two undergraduates, we made several major discoveries regarding the impact of the cosmic web on galaxies according to state-of-the-art galaxy formation/evolution theory.  According to these theoretical models: 1) Galaxies that currently reside closer to filament spines or cosmic web 'nodes' (the intersections of filaments) should have decreased star formation activity and and less gas out of which to form new stars. 2) Enabled by the fact that galaxy simulations can show evolution over time, we find that this environmental influence might be a relatively recent phenomenon in cosmic time, as these trends appear to be independent of galaxy location with the respect to the large scale structure when the Universe was half its current age. 3) When we characterize the large-scale structure using our new filament line density metric, we find that this is a critical factor, as galaxies that belong to denser filaments are more greatly affected than less dense filaments. 4) When comparing similar galaxies and cosmic web environments from the simulations and observations in the real Universe, theory overpredicts how much galaxies should be forming stars and how much gas they have to form stars.  This is particularly strong in highly underdense voids, where the discrepancy is strongest. 5) While the simulations predict suppressed gas reservoirs and star formation at closer distances to filaments, the observations seem to show the opposite.

Also, this award funded producing potential applications of using astrophysical data to create art as a means of improving attitudes towards science, technology, engineering, and mathematics among high school students. These could be modified and adapted to middle school or other grade levels as well.

The activities supported by this award have directly led to three refereed publications in the Astrophysical Journal and several conference presentations, including three topical conferences and meetings of the American Astronomical Society and Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science.
